[Portrait]Dycedarg
[Dialog]Our little mockingbird is taken wing, Gaffgarion,
and it leaves me wroth.
We cannot have her free. Catch her, crush
her, and make silent her song. Lady Agrias's
and the others' as well.{END}

[Portrait]Gaffgarion
[Dialog]And <Ramza>?{END}

The fool. He soils our name, dogs
my every move.

I thought this a chance to let him
learn the harsh truths of the world.
But the boy is too stubborn.{END}

Too much of his father's penchant
for justice, that one.{END}

Father coddled the boy too much.


If he stands aside, more the better.
Should he interfere, there's naught
can be done.{END}

And you his brother.
The blood curdles.{END}

If the cardinal moves to defend
the mockingbird, what then?

Duke Larg himself could not
reach them in umbrage of the
Church's wing.{END}

Worry not. That potentiality has been
addressed.{END}

Ever three steps ahead. You are a
frightening man, Dycedarg Beoulve.{END}

Truly? Would it not be prudent, then,
to better guard your tongue?

There are so many frightening ways

Come now, my lord, I am your
ever-faithful man!

And not near so stubborn as a
particular Knight Devout-if I

Be bold. But let there be no more

On the matter of missteps, what
buffoon did you charge with the
princess's kidnapping?
We were beset in Dorter as we
gave chase. Not quite how we'd
discussed, I'm sure you'd agree.{END}

The men I sent were found dead in
the woods near the monastery.

Someone has caught wind of our plan,
and seems intent on disrupting it.

No matter. As long as Ovelia remains

I pray you're right,
for both our sakes.{END}
